segments.title: Types of Machine Learning
segments.text: Machine Learning can be broadly categorized into two main types: Supervised Learning and Unsupervised Learning. Supervised Learning involves learning from labeled data and is used for tasks such as classification and regression. Unsupervised Learning, on the other hand, involves learning from unlabeled data and is commonly used for clustering.

segments.title: k-Nearest Neighbours (k-NN)
segments.text: k-Nearest Neighbours (k-NN) is a simple, non-parametric, and versatile algorithm used for classification and regression. It works by finding the k closest training examples in the feature space to the new point that needs to be classified. The classification is then determined by a majority vote of its 'neighbours,' with the new data point assigned to the class most common among its k nearest neighbours.

segments.title: Types of Machine Learning
segments.text: Machine learning can be broadly categorized into two main types: Supervised Learning and Unsupervised Learning. Supervised Learning involves training models on labeled data and includes tasks like classification, where the model predicts categories, and regression, where the model predicts continuous values. Unsupervised Learning, on the other hand, involves training models on unlabeled data to find patterns or groupings, as seen in clustering tasks.

segments.title: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) for Regression
segments.text: K-Nearest Neighbors can also be used for regression tasks. Instead of classifying data points, KNN regression predicts the value of a new data point based on the values of its *k* nearest neighbors. The average or median value of these neighbors is used to make the prediction.

segments.question: What is the difference between K-Nearest Neighbors for classification and regression?
segments.answer: The difference is that KNN for classification assigns a class to a new data point based on the most common class among its nearest neighbors (1 point), whereas KNN for regression predicts a continuous value based on the average or median of the values of its nearest neighbors (1 point).

segments.title: Clustering
segments.text: Clustering is an unsupervised learning task used in data analysis that involves grouping a set of objects into clusters. The objects in the same cluster are more similar to each other than to those in other clusters. Applications of clustering include market research, pattern recognition, data analysis, and image processing. An example of clustering is customer segmentation, where customers are grouped based on purchasing behavior.

segments.question: What is clustering and give an example of its application?
segments.answer: Clustering is an unsupervised learning task that groups objects into clusters where objects within the same cluster are more similar to each other (1 point). An example of clustering is customer segmentation, where customers are grouped based on purchasing behavior (1 point).

segments.title: k-Means
segments.text: k-Means is an algorithm used for clustering. It aims to partition a set of data points into k clusters in which each data point belongs to the cluster with the nearest mean. This results in a partitioning of the data space into Voronoi cells. k-Means is commonly used because of its simplicity and efficiency.

segments.question: What is the k-Means algorithm and how is it used?
segments.answer: The k-Means algorithm is a clustering algorithm that partitions data points into k clusters (1 point), where each data point is assigned to the cluster with the nearest mean (1 point). It is used to efficiently group data into clusters based on similarity (1 point).

segments.title: Polynomial Regression
segments.text: Polynomial regression is a type of regression analysis where the relationship between the independent variable and the dependent variable is modeled as an nth degree polynomial. It is particularly useful for describing curvilinear relationships, where the connection between the variables is not a straight line but can be represented more accurately with a polynomial equation.

segments.question: What is polynomial regression and when is it used?
segments.answer: Polynomial regression is a type of regression analysis (1 point) where the relationship between the independent and dependent variable is modeled as an nth degree polynomial (1 point). It is used for describing curvilinear relationships (1 point), where a linear model is insufficient (1 point).

segments.title: Clustering

It’s a method of unsupervised learning, and a common technique for statistical data analysis used in many fields.

segments.question: What is clustering in the context of machine learning?
segments.answer: Clustering is a machine learning technique (1 point) that involves grouping a set of objects (1 point) so that those within the same cluster are more similar to each other (1 point) than to those in other clusters (1 point). It is a form of unsupervised learning (1 point).

segments.title: k-Means
segments.text: k-Means is a popular clustering algorithm used in unsupervised learning. It aims to partition n observations into k clusters in which each observation belongs to the cluster with the nearest mean. The algorithm works iteratively to assign each data point to one of k groups based on the features that are provided. k-Means is often used for customer segmentation, where customers are grouped based on features like purchasing behavior.

segments.question: What is the k-Means algorithm and how is it used?
segments.answer: The k-Means algorithm is a clustering algorithm (1 point) used to partition observations into k clusters (1 point) based on their nearest mean (1 point). It is commonly used in unsupervised learning tasks such as customer segmentation (1 point).

segments.title: Regression
segments.text: Regression is a supervised learning task used in machine learning that involves predicting a continuous quantity. Unlike classification, which predicts categorical outcomes, regression aims to forecast outcomes that are real or continuous values, such as ‘salary’ or ‘house price’. Regression algorithms use input features from the data to predict the output values. Examples of regression tasks include predicting the price of a house based on characteristics like size, location, and number of bedrooms. Common regression algorithms include Univariate Linear Regression and Multivariate Linear Regression.

segments.question: What is the goal of regression in machine learning and how does it differ from classification?
segments.answer: The goal of regression in machine learning (1 point) is to predict continuous quantities (1 point), as opposed to classification which predicts categorical outcomes (1 point). Examples of continuous quantities are 'salary' and 'house price' (1 point).

segments.title: Univariate Linear Regression
segments.text: Univariate Linear Regression is a type of regression algorithm where the prediction of the output is based on a single input feature. The relationship between the input and the output is assumed to be linear, and the algorithm finds the best-fitting straight line through the data points. This line is defined by the equation y = mx + c, where 'y' is the output variable, 'm' is the slope, 'x' is the input feature, and 'c' is the y-intercept.

segments.question: What is Univariate Linear Regression, and what does it assume about the relationship between the input and output?
segments.answer: Univariate Linear Regression (1 point) is a regression algorithm where the output prediction is based on a single input feature (1 point). It assumes that the relationship between the input and output is linear (1 point), represented by a straight line defined by the equation y = mx + c (1 point).

segments.title: Simple Linear Regression
segments.text: Simple linear regression is a statistical method used to predict the value of a dependent variable based on the value of a single independent variable. It assumes a linear relationship between the two variables.

segments.question: What is simple linear regression?
segments.answer: Simple linear regression is a statistical method (1 point) used to predict the value of a dependent variable (1 point) based on the value of a single independent variable (1 point), assuming a linear relationship between the two (1 point).

segments.title: Multivariate Linear Regression
segments.text: Multivariate linear regression is an extension of simple linear regression that involves multiple independent variables to predict the dependent variable. It finds the linear relationship between the dependent variable and each of the independent variables.

segments.question: What is multivariate linear regression?
segments.answer: Multivariate linear regression is a statistical method (1 point) that involves multiple independent variables (1 point) to predict the dependent variable (1 point) and finds the linear relationship between them (1 point).

segments.title: Hippocampus-Cortex Dialogue and Memory Consolidation
segments.text: The model of memory consolidation that the lecture refers to involves an interaction between the hippocampus and the cortex. The hippocampus serves as a central hub for new memories and exhibits significant plasticity and connectivity with the rest of the brain. Synaptic changes occur in the hippocampus with the help of neuromodulators such as acetylcholine, which is essential for securing long-term memory.

segments.question: How does the hippocampus contribute to memory consolidation according to the model referred to in the lecture?
segments.answer: The hippocampus serves as a central hub for new memories (1 point), exhibits significant plasticity and connectivity with the rest of the brain (1 point), and undergoes synaptic changes with the help of neuromodulators such as acetylcholine (1 point), which is essential for securing long-term memory (1 point).

segments.title: Clive Wearing's Case and the Role of the Hippocampus
segments.text: Clive Wearing's case illustrates the crucial role of the hippocampus in forming long-term memories. Due to damage to his hippocampus, Clive is unable to form explicit memories that are consciously accessible, leading to a dissociation with consciousness where he can learn new things without being aware of it.

segments.question: Why is Clive Wearing unable to form new long-term memories?
segments.answer: Clive Wearing is unable to form new long-term memories because he lacks a functioning hippocampus (1 point), which is essential for creating explicit memories that are consciously accessible (1 point). As a result, there is a dissociation with consciousness (1 point).

segments.title: Impliciet versus Expliciet Geheugen
segments.text: Impliciet geheugen verwijst naar het onbewuste geheugen voor vaardigheden en hoe dingen gedaan worden, zoals fietsen of pianospelen. Expliciet geheugen daarentegen is het bewuste geheugen voor feitelijke informatie en persoonlijke ervaringen, zoals het herinneren van een verjaardag of een gebeurtenis uit de geschiedenis.

segments.question: Wat is het verschil tussen impliciet en expliciet geheugen?
segments.answer: Impliciet geheugen is onbewust en voor vaardigheden en procedures (1 point), terwijl expliciet geheugen bewust is en voor feitelijke informatie en persoonlijke ervaringen (1 point).

segments.title: Impliciete Herinneringen en de Cortex
segments.text: De cortex kan impliciete herinneringen vastleggen zonder de hulp van de hippocampus. Deze herinneringen vormen geen bewuste episodes en zijn onbewust. Dit suggereert dat voor bewuste toegang tot het geheugen, geheugensporen die via de hippocampus zijn gevormd nodig zijn. De exacte reden waarom dit gebeurt, is nog niet volledig begrepen.

segments.question: Wat zijn impliciete herinneringen en hoe worden ze vastgelegd?
segments.answer: Impliciete herinneringen zijn herinneringen die onbewust zijn en geen bewuste episodes vormen (1 point). Ze kunnen worden vastgelegd door de cortex zonder de hulp van de hippocampus (1 point).

segments.title: Geheugensysteem
segments.text: Het geheugensysteem omvat verschillende processen en regio's in de hersenen, waaronder een 'links systeem', bekend als de hippocampus, en een 'trace systeem', waar uiteindelijk alle herinneringen worden opgeslagen. Daarnaast speelt een modulatoiresysteem, diep in het voorbrein, een rol door het verspreiden van belangrijke stoffen zoals neuro-acetylcholine, welke essentieel zijn voor dit proces.

segments.question: Wat houdt het geheugensysteem in en welke onderdelen zijn erbij betrokken?
segments.answer: Het geheugensysteem omvat de hippocampus als het 'links systeem' (1 point) en een 'trace systeem' voor het opslaan van herinneringen (1 point). Een modulatoiresysteem in het voorbrein verspreidt stoffen zoals neuro-acetylcholine voor dit proces (1 point).

segments.title: Geheugensporen
segments.text: Geheugensporen verwijzen naar de fysieke en chemische veranderingen in de hersenen die geassocieerd zijn met het opslaan van herinneringen. Deze sporen worden gevormd en opgeslagen in het 'trace systeem' van de hersenen.

segments.question: Wat zijn geheugensporen?
segments.answer: Geheugensporen zijn fysieke en chemische veranderingen in de hersenen (1 point) die geassocieerd zijn met het opslaan van herinneringen (1 point).

segments.title: Verband met Alzheimer en Acetylcholine
segments.text: Acetylcholine is een neurotransmitter die een belangrijke rol speelt in het geheugen en het leerproces. Een tekort aan acetylcholine wordt vaak geassocieerd met de ziekte van Alzheimer, een hersenaandoening die leidt tot geheugenverlies en cognitieve achteruitgang.

segments.question: Wat is het verband tussen Acetylcholine en Alzheimer?

answer.content: Acetylcholine is een neurotransmitter die belangrijk is voor geheugen en leren (1 punt). Een tekort eraan wordt geassocieerd met de ziekte van Alzheimer (1 punt), wat leidt tot geheugenverlies en cognitieve achteruitgang (1 punt).
